facts.text: Writ Petition No. 23 of 1974 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 23 of 1974. Petition Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Petitioner detained by order of District Magistrate, Varanasi on 3rd September 1973 under section 3(1)(a)(iii) of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: the order of the District Magistrate, Varanasi, of 3rd September, 1973, whereby the petitioner was detained under sub-section  iii  of clause  a  of sub-section  1  .of section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  briefly the Act .

facts.text: Grounds of detention served on petitioner on 7th September 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention were served on the petitioner on 7th September, 1973.

facts.text: Petitioner and associates charge sheeted by Mohania Police on 28-11-1966 for offence under section 7 F.C. Act and 125 DIR 1962, case pending in Magistrate Court Bhabhua Bihar, stayed by Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 3 That you and your other associates have been charge sheeted by Mohania Police on 28-11-66 for the offence punishable under section 7 F.C. Act and 125 DIR 1962 and the case is still pending in the Court, Magistrate of Bhabhua  Bihar  as the proceedings have been stayed by the orders of the High Court, Patna.

facts.text: Petitioner started firm M/s Shyam Sunder Ashok Kumar in Mohalla Machchodari P.S. Kotwali Varanasi in 1966 or 1967, associating minor son Ashok Kumar, brother Shyam Sunder and family lady nominally while transacting business himself for illegal activities.

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 4 That with a view to companytinue your anti-social activities and to save yourself from the clutches of law you have started a firm under the name and style of M s Shyam Sunder Ashok Kumar, in Mohalla Machchodari P. S. Kotwali, Varanasi City some time in the year 1966 or 1967 and You have purposely associated your minor son Ashok Kumar, your brother Shyam Sunder and a lady of your family as partners in the said firm only in name while, in fact, you are actively transacting the entire business of the said firm to carry on the illegal activities.

facts.text: Petitioner smuggled large quantity of maize, bajra and jawar to godown at Mohania Bihar through firm, evidenced by sales on 21-6-1973, 26-6-1973, 7-7-1973, 16-6-1973, 16-7-1973.

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 5 That taking undue advantage of the acute shortage of the foodgrains in the state due to the failure of the rains disrupt the fair and equitable distribution amongst the public you have succeeded in getting large quantity of maize, bajra and jawar and smuggled to and stored in your goodown at Mohania  Bihar , a number-producing area of these foodgrains in the State of Bihar, just on the border of U.P. through your said firm which will be evidenced by the facts given below Then follows a detailed list of sales of bajra, jawar and maize to numerous persons as per cash memos mentioned therein showing sales, on 21-6-1973, 26-1973, 7-7-1973, 16-6- 1973 and 16-7-1973

facts.text: Persons named in sales are neither foodgrains Arhatias nor retail shopkeepers at Chandsuli Bazar or village.

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 6 That the persons named above are neither foodgrains Arhatias number retail shopkeepers either at Chandsuli Bazar or in Chandsuli village.

facts.text: Sales fictitious to smuggle bajra, jawar, maize to Bihar, from where booked by rail to Delhi and Poona: 225 bags jawar to Delhi, 116 bajra Poona, 150 bajra Poona, 220 bajra Poona, 229 jawar Poona, consignments to self, no such persons found.

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 7 That the aforesaid sales are fictitious and have been shown with a view to smuggle bajra, jawar and maize to Bihar from where enough quantities of bajra and jawar have been booked by rail to Delhi and Poona as shown below Then is given a list of various bookings of 225 bags of jWar to Delhi, 116 bags of bajra to Poona, 150 bags of bajra to Poona, 220 bags of bajra to Poona and 229 bags of jawar to Poona and even railway wagon numbers are mentioned. The 7th ground ends as under -- All these companysignments were booked to self. The companysigners of aft these companysignments were searched at Mohania on the address given in the railway records but numbersuch persons or Bhandar were available on that address.

facts.text: Five trucks UPF 2039, USF 3253, UPF 2927, USS 7745, UPF 2015 loaded with jawar and bajra apprehended by Mohania Police on 2-3-1973 (2/3 July 1973) for smuggling from UP to Bihar at petitioner's instance.

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 8 That five trucks bearing registration No. UPF 2039, USF 3253, UPF 2927, USS 7745 and UPF 2015 loaded with jawar and bajra were apprehended by Mohania Police on 2- 3-1973  2/3 July 1973?  on the ground that all the trucks belonged to Uttar Pradesh and the jawar and bajra loaded on them were being smuggled from U.P. to Bihar at your instance.

facts.text: Shortage found in stock of firm Shyam Sunder Ashok Kumar on 17-7-1973 by Deputy Regional Marketing Officer Varanasi: 3 bags rice No.2, 499 bags gram, 70 bags Matar, 90 bags Dal matar.

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 9 That 3 bags of rice No. 2, 499 bags gram, 70 bags of Matar and 90 bags of Dal matar were found short on the actual verification of the stock of firm Shyam Sunder Ashok Kumar on 17-7-1973 by Deputy Regional Marketing Officer, Varanasi  Enforcement .

facts.text: Firm did not maintain stock register, satta Bhai since 1970 for oil-seeds, but 305 bags Tisi and 10 bags Sarson found on 17-7-73.

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 10 That the firm Shyam Sunder Ashok Kumar have number maintained any stock register and satta Bhai since 1970 of oil- seeds and oil-seeds product but at the time of checking on 17-7-73, 305 bags of Tisi and 10 bags of Sarson were found

facts.text: Petitioner applied to Allahabad High Court under Article 226 and section 491 CrPC, dismissed by Division Bench on 26th November 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner applied to the High Court of Allahabad under Article 226 of the Constitution read with section 491 of the, Code of Criminal Procedure for quashing the order of detention and the same was dismissed by the Division Bench on 26th November, 1973.

facts.text: Special leave to appeal obtained on 19th December 1973, registered as Criminal Appeal No. 231 of 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner obtained special leave to appeal against the judgment on 19th December, 1973 and the same has been registered as Criminal Appeal No. 231 of 1973.

facts.text: Writ petition No. 23 of 1974 filed before Supreme Court on 20th December 1973 against State Government confirmation order of 21st November 1973 under section 12(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner also filed writ petition No. 23 of 1974 before this Court under Article 32 of the Constitution on 20th December, 1973, against the order of the State Government of 21st November, 1973, companyfirming the aforesaid order of detention under sect-ion 12.  1  of the Act

facts.text: Rule nisi issued by Supreme Court on 31st January 1974.

anchor.surface_text: and rule nisi was issued on 31st January, 1974.

facts.text: Mohania Police Station case in ground No. 3 still pending, admitted by counsel for State.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted by Mr. Uniyal, learned companynsel for the State, that the Mohania Police Station case referred to in ground No. 3 is s. ill pending in the criminal companyrt in Bihar.

facts.text: First information report lodged by Inspector of Police, Karm Nasha Check Post on 11th October 1964, charge-sheet 28th/29th November 1966.

anchor.surface_text: What is referred to in ground No. 3 is the criminal case under section 7 of the Essential Commodities Act and rule 125 of the Defence of India Rules, 1962. This has reference to the first information report lodged by the Inspector of Police, Karm Nasha Check Post, Camp Mohania Arrah, Bihar, on the 11he October, 1964  Annexure-P at page 137 of the writ petition . The relative charge-sheet dated 29th November,. 1966  28th November, 1966?

facts.text: Patna High Court quashed detention order of 19th July 1965 on 21st August 1965 based on same FIR of 11th October 1964.

anchor.surface_text: It should be mentioned here that the High Court of Patna in Criminal Writ Jurisdiction cases Nos. 39 and 40 of 1965 by order dated 21st August, 1965, quashed an order of detention of the petitioner made on 19th July, 1965, based on the allegations in the same first information report of 11th October, 1964,

facts.text: Ground No. 8 subject of criminal case with FIR of 3rd July 1973, still pending.

anchor.surface_text: Again ground No. 8 is also the subject matter of criminal case with reference to the first information report of 3rd July 1973  Annexure 12 at page 288 of the writ petition . There is numbercontroversy that the said criminal case is still pending.

facts.text: Grounds 9 and 10 covered by FIR 5th August 1973, charge-sheet 19th September 1973 under s.3/7 EC Act, pending in Varanasi court.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly grounds Nos. 9 and 10 are companyered by a criminal case with reference to first information report dated 5th August, 1973 and the relative charge-sheet dated 19th September, 1973 under section 3/7 of the Essential Commodities Act, pending in the criminal companyrt at Varanasi P. .

facts.text: Supreme Court holds detention order invalid due to grounds being subject of pending criminal trials.

anchor.surface_text: The companyclusion is, therefore, irresistible in this case that the, impugned order is invalid and the detention in this case must be held to be illegal.

facts.text: Writ petition and appeal allowed, Allahabad High Court judgment set aside, petitioner to be released forthwith.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition and the appeal are allowed. The judgment of the Allahabad High Court is set aside and in the view we have taken we do number feel called upon to pronounce upon the various reasons given by the High Court in rejecting the petition. The rule nisi is made absolute. The petitioner shall be released forth with from the jail unless he is required in any other case.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that in a case of preventive detention the grounds must be clear and definite to enable the detenu to make an effective representation to the Government to induce the authorities to take a view in his favour. He must, therefore, have a real and affective opportunity to make his representation to establish his innocence.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that in an order under the present Act the decision of the authority is a subjective one and if one of the grounds is non-existent or irrelevant or is not available under the law, the entire detention order will fall since it is not possible to predicate as to whether the detaining authority would have made an order for detention even in the absence of non-existent or irrelevant ground.

concepts.interpretation: Since grounds based on pending trials are irrelevant, entire detention order invalid.

arguments.claim: In preventive detention, grounds must be clear and definite to enable detenu to make effective representation; facing criminal trial on same facts denies this opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that in a case of preventive detention the grounds must be clear and definite to enable the detenu to make an effective representation... Being faced with a criminal prosecution which is pending against him all through, we are clearly of the view that the detenu has not got a proper...

arguments.claim: Detaining authority cannot resort to parallel detention and criminal prosecution on self-same facts; such grounds introduce serious infirmity.

anchor.surface_text: The position will be, however, entirely different if the authority concerned makes an order of detention under the Act and also prosecutes him in a criminal case on the self-same facts. This, in our view, is totally barred. The detaining authority cannot take recourse to two parallel...

arguments.claim: Impugned detention order invalid as based on irrelevant grounds from pending criminal prosecutions.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion is, therefore, irresistible in this case that the, impugned order is invalid and the detention in this case must be held to be illegal.

holdings.text: Ground No. 3 is not merely descriptive but forms the subject matter of a pending criminal trial and is the corner-stone of Ground No. 4.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore, unable to accept the submission of Mr. Uniyal that ground No. 3 is merely descriptive and is not germane with regard to the order of detention. On the other hand, there is great force in the submission of Mr. Anthony that ground No. 3 is the corner-stone of ground No. 4. It is clear that ground No. 3 is covered by a prosecution

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge-sheet details inter-state illegal activities linking to formation of firm in Ground 4; directly relevant to detention satisfaction.

holdings.text: Grounds Nos. 3, 8, 9 and 10 are subject matters of pending criminal prosecutions.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted by Mr. Uniyal, learned counsel for the State, that the Mohania Police Station case referred to in ground No. 3 is still pending in the criminal court in Bihar. ... Similarly grounds Nos. 9 and 10 are covered by a criminal case with reference to first information report dated 5th August, 1973 and the relative charge-sheet dated 19th September, 1973 under section 3/7 of the Essential Commodities Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted for Ground 3; FIR and charge-sheets confirm for Grounds 8, 9-10 still sub judice.

holdings.text: Detenu cannot make effective representation against grounds that are subject of pending criminal trial.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that in a case of preventive detention the grounds must be clear and definite to enable the detenu to make an effective representation to the Government to induce the authorities to take a view in his favour. He must, therefore, have a real and effective opportunity to make his representation to establish his innocence. Being faced with a criminal prosecution which is pending against him all through,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pending prosecution denies real opportunity to disclose defense without prejudicing criminal trial.

holdings.text: Detaining authority barred from two parallel proceedings of detention and criminal prosecution on same facts.

anchor.surface_text: The position will be, however, entirely different if the authority concerned makes an order of detention under the Act and also prosecutes him in a criminal case on the self-same facts. This, in our view, is totally barred. The detaining authority cannot take recourse to two parallel and simultaneous proceedings nor can take recourse to a ground which is the subject matter of a criminal trial

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parallel proceedings introduce serious infirmity; authority must choose one mode.

holdings.text: Mohd. Salim Khan case distinguishable as it involved discharge, not pending prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Uniyal has, however, drawn our attention to a decision of this Court in Mohd. Salim Khan... The mere fact, however, that criminal proceedings in connection with the same incidents had been adopted against the petitioner and he had been discharged by the trying Magistrate does not mean that no valid order of detention could be passed against him in connection with those very incidents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discharge due to insufficient evidence under CrPC differs from ongoing trial where evidence is tested.

holdings.text: If one ground is non-existent, irrelevant or not available under law, entire detention order falls due to subjective satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that in an order under the present Act the decision of the authority is a subjective one and if one of the grounds is non-existent or irrelevant or is not available under the law, the entire detention order will fall since it is not possible to predicate as to whether the detaining authority would have made an order for detention even in the absence of non-existent or irrelevant ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cannot sever grounds in subjective satisfaction; bad ground invalidates whole.

holdings.text: Impugned detention order is invalid and detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion is, therefore, irresistible in this case that the, impugned order is invalid and the detention in this case must be held to be illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grounds from pending prosecutions irrelevant, vitiating order under settled law.

holdings.text: Writ petition and appeal allowed; Allahabad High Court judgment set aside; petitioner released forthwith.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition and the appeal are allowed. The judgment of the Allahabad High Court is set aside and in the view we have taken we do not feel called upon to pronounce upon the various reasons given by the High Court in rejecting the petition. The rule nisi is made absolute. The petitioner shall be released forthwith

holdings.reasoning_summary: Flows from invalidity of detention order.

precedents.case_name: Mohd. Salim Khan v. Shri C. C. Bose
precedents.cited_proposition: Mere discharge by magistrate in criminal proceedings on same incidents does not invalidate detention order or make it mala fide if detaining authority has subjective satisfaction about activities
precedents.cited_holding: From the mere fact, therefore, that the Magistrate discharged the petitioner from the criminal case lodged against him it cannot be said that the impugned order was incompetent, nor can it be inferred that it was without a basis or mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that in a case of preventive detention the grounds must be clear and definite to enable the detenu to make an effective representation to the Government to induce the authorities to take a view in his favour. anchor.surface_text: The position will be, however, entirely different if the authority concerned makes an order of detention under the Act and also prosecutes him in a criminal case on the self-same facts. This, in our view, is totally barred. The detaining authority cannot take recourse to two parallel and simultaneous proceedings nor can take recourse to a ground which is the subject matter of a criminal trial

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that in an order under the present Act the decision of the authority is a subjective one and if one of the grounds is non-existent or irrelevant or is not available under the law, the entire detention order will fall since it is not possible to predicate as to whether the detaining authority would have made an order for detention even in the absence of non-existent or irrelevant ground.

The writ petition and the appeal are allowed. The judgment of the Allahabad High Court is set aside and in the view we have taken we do number feel called upon to pronounce upon the various reasons given by the High Court in rejecting the petition.
